facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 870 of 1973 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 870 of 1973.

facts.text: Appeal from Judgment and Order dated 26th March 1973 of Patna High Court in Election Petition No. 1 of 1972.

anchor.surface_text: From the Judgment and Order dated the 26th March 1973 of the Patna High Court in Election Petition No. 1 of 1972.

facts.text: Bye-election to Lok Sabha from Darbhanga Parliamentary Constituency held on January 30, 1972.

anchor.surface_text: In the bye-election to the Lok Sabha from Darbhanga Parliamentary Constituency held on January 30, 1972, the respondent Lalit Narain Mishra-a candidate of the Indian National Congress- was declared elected on February 2, 1972, by a. margin of 91,078 votes against his rival Ramsewak Yadava candidate of the Socialist Party at that election.

facts.text: Respondent Lalit Narain Mishra, Indian National Congress candidate, declared elected on February 2, 1972.

anchor.surface_text: the respondent Lalit Narain Mishra-a candidate of the Indian National Congress- was declared elected on February 2, 1972, by a. margin of 91,078 votes against his rival Ramsewak Yadava candidate of the Socialist Party at that election.

facts.text: Lalit Narain Mishra elected by margin of 91,078 votes against Ramsewak Yadava of Socialist Party.

anchor.surface_text: by a. margin of 91,078 votes against his rival Ramsewak Yadava candidate of the Socialist Party at that election.

facts.text: Appellant, an elector in the constituency, presented election petition on March 20, 1972 (Monday).

anchor.surface_text: The appellant an elector in that companystituency presented an election petition on Monday, March 20, 1972, instead of on Saturday. March 18, 1972, which was the last day of limitation.

facts.text: Last day of limitation for election petition was March 18, 1972 (Saturday).

anchor.surface_text: instead of on Saturday. March 18, 1972, which was the last day of limitation.

facts.text: Patna High Court dismissed election petition as time-barred.

anchor.surface_text: The petition, however, was dismissed by the High Court as being time-barred.

facts.text: Appeal filed under section 116A of Representation of the People Act, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: Against that judgment and order this appeal has been filed under s. 116-A of the Representation of the People Act, 1951  hereinafter referred to as the Act .

facts.text: Section 80A added by Amendment Act 47 of 1966, giving High Court jurisdiction to try election petitions.

anchor.surface_text: It may be mentioned that s. 80-A was added to the Act by the Amendment Act 47 of 1966, whereunder the High Court was given .jurisdiction to try election petitions.

facts.text: Section 81 prescribes 45 days from date of election for presenting election petition.

anchor.surface_text: Section 81 prescribes the period of 45 days from the date of the election of a returned candidate within which an election petition calling in question any election on one or more grounds specified in sub-s.  1  of s. 100 and s. 101 has to be presented to the High Court.

facts.text: Petition presented beyond 45 days, so to be dismissed under s.86.

anchor.surface_text: There is numberdoubt that election petition in this case has been presented beyond the period of 45 days and has necessarily to be dismissed.

facts.text: Petitioner claims court closed on Saturday March 18, 1972 as judges do not sit.

anchor.surface_text: What we have to companysider, however, is that whether having regard to the requirements of Tr. 6 and 7 of the Rules for the Disposal of Election Petitions framed by the Patna High Court, an election petition should only be filed before a Judge of the High Court sitting in open Court, and it companyld number be filed on a Saturday when the Judges do number sit

facts.text: Court finds High Court not closed on Saturday even if judges do not sit.

anchor.surface_text: A long companyrse of decisions have held that a Court is number closed numberwithstanding the fact that Judges do number sit on any day if otherwise the Court is open on that day.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds section 5 of Limitation Act not applicable to election petitions.

anchor.surface_text: For all these reasons we have companye to the companyclusion that the provisions of s. 5 of the Limitation Act do number govern the filing of election petitions or their trial

facts.text: Patna High Court has Rules 6 and 7 for presentation of election petitions.

anchor.surface_text: Rules 6 7 of the Election Rules are as follows Subject always to the orders of the Judge, before a formal presentation of the election petition is made to the Judge in open Court, it shall be presented to the Stamp Reporter of the Court,

facts.text: Election petition could be presented to Registrar on Saturday under r.26 if no bench sitting.

anchor.surface_text: In our view, therefore, reading rr. 6 and 7 with r. 26, there can be numbermanner of doubt that an election petition can be presented on the last day of limitation even when the Judges are number sitting to receive or entertain an election petition to the Registrar

facts.text: Patna High Court held in Md. Gwais v. Phul Bibi that applications can be filed on Saturday.

anchor.surface_text: Infact the Patna High Court had, on a similar point, held nearly seven years ago in Md. Gwais and others v. Phul Bibi and others,  1  a companyy of which has been placed before us, that where under r. 13 Part 11, Chapter VII,

facts.text: Supreme Court dismisses the appeal.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal as well as C.M.P.

facts.text: Section 81 requires presentation within 45 days, non-compliance leads to dismissal under s.86.

anchor.surface_text: If the provisions of s. 81 are number companyplied with, s. 86 requires that the High Court shall dismiss the petition.
Against that judgment and order this appeal has been filed under s. 116-A of the Representation of the People Act, 1951  hereinafter referred to as the Act .

issues.text: Is the Court closed on Saturday, when the Judges do not sit for the purposes either of s. 10 of the General Clauses Act, or s. 4 of the Limitation Act?

anchor.surface_text: Is the Court closed on Saturday, when the Judges do number sit  1  for the purposes either of s. 10 of the General Clauses Act, or s. 4 of the Limitation Act?

issues.text: By virtue of s. 29(2) of the Limitation Act, are the provisions of ss. 4 to 24 of the said Act applicable to election petitions?

anchor.surface_text: By virtue of s. 29 2  of the Limitation Act, are the provisions of ss. 4 to 24 of the said Act applicable to election petitions?

issues.text: If they are, and s. 5 of the Limitation Act is applicable, do the facts of the case warrant condonation of delay?

arguments.claim: Election petition could not be filed on Saturday March 18, 1972 because Judges do not sit and rules 6 and 7 require presentation to Judge in open Court

anchor.surface_text: What we have to consider, however, is that whether having regard to the requirements of r. 6 and 7 of the Rules for the Disposal of Election Petitions framed by the Patna High Court, an election petition should only be filed before a Judge of the High Court sitting in open Court, and it could not be filed on a Saturday when the Judges do not sit and hence the filing of that petition on Monday, March 20, 1972, Sunday being a holiday, is in time.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: , or in their absence to the Assistant Registrar, who shall certify thereon that such memorandum of appeal or application was on that day presented to

arguments.court_reasoning: Rules 6 and 7 read with r.26 allow presentation to Registrar on Saturday when no Bench sitting; precedents hold court not closed if office open

arguments.claim: Even if s.4 of Limitation Act applies, it does not because election petition is neither suit, appeal nor application notwithstanding definition in s.2(b)

anchor.surface_text: It was sought to be contended that even if the limitation Act applies s. 4 would not apply because an election petition is neither a suit, nor an appeal nor an application, notwithstanding the definition of application contained in s. 2 b  of the Limitation Act as including a petition.

arguments.court_reasoning: Unnecessary to decide as s.10 General Clauses Act applies regardless

arguments.court_reasoning: No inconsistency; r.26 provides for contingency when no Judge/Bench available

arguments.claim: r.26 refers only to application not to petition so inapplicable to election petition

anchor.surface_text: It was, however, contended by the learned Advocate for the appellant, though on a farther consideration he did not think that he could sustain it, that r.26 makes a reference to an application and not to a petition as such that rule is inapplicable

anchor.surface_text: It is further submitted that r. 26 has no application as it is inconsistent with r. 7 because under the latter rule the date of presentation to a Judge or a Bench is deemed to be the date of the filing of the election petition for the purpose of limitation,

court_response_anchor.surface_text: itation Act, sub-s.  2  of s. 29 stands directly attracted and s. 3 and other section shall apply in so far as, and to the extent to which, they are n

arguments.court_reasoning: No inconsistency; r.7(1) does not cover case where no Judges sit; r.26 fills gap

arguments.claim: Court is not closed on Saturday notwithstanding Judges do not sit if Court otherwise open

anchor.surface_text: A long course of decisions have held that a Court is not closed notwithstanding the fact that Judges do not sit on any day if otherwise the Court is open on that day. Harries, C.J., during the course of the arguments in Lachmeshwar Prasad Shukul v. Girdhari Lal Chaudhuri

arguments.claim: s.10 General Clauses Act applies to election petitions

anchor.surface_text: It is, in our view unnecessary to examine the submission in this context because even if s. 4 of the Limitation Act does not apply, S. 10 of the General Clauses Act will certainly apply to election petit-ions to be filed under the Act as held by this Court in H.H. Raja Harinder Singh v. Karnail Singh

arguments.claim: Patna HC Rules r.13 allows filing applications on Saturday; consistent with election petitions

anchor.surface_text: This conclusion is further reinforced by a reference to r. 13 of Chapter 11 part I of the Patna High Court Rules whereun- der the Registrar has power to receive an appeal under clause 10 of the Letters Patent, to receive an application for probate or Letters of Administration

anchor.surface_text: In our view, therefore, reading rr. 6 and 7 with r. 26, there can be no manner of doubt that an election petition can be presented on the last day of limitation even when the Judges are not sitting to receive or entertain an election petition to the Registrar

anchor.surface_text: Infact the Patna High Court had, on a similar point, held nearly seven years ago in Md. Gwais and others v. Phul Bibi and others,  a copy of which has been placed before us, that where under r. 13 Part 11, Chapter VII,

arguments.claim: Provisions of s.5 Limitation Act do not apply to election petitions as RPA is complete self-contained code

anchor.surface_text: For all these reasons we have come to the conclusion that the provisions of s. 5 of the Limitation Act do not govern the filing of election petitions or their trial

arguments.claim: s.29(2) Limitation Act applies only insofar as not expressly excluded by special law; RPA scheme excludes ss.4-24

anchor.surface_text: Whether s.5 is appli- cable to election petitions filed under s. 81 of the Act will depend upon the terms of s. 29 2  of the Limitation Act.

arguments.claim: s.86 RPA mirrors s.3 Limitation Act; non-compliance with s.81 mandates dismissal without condonation

anchor.surface_text: The provisions of s. 3 of the Limitation Act that a suit instituted, appeal preferred and application made after the prescribed period shall be dismissed are provided for in s. 86 of the Act

arguments.claim: RPA ss.81,82,117 all mandatory; cannot apply s.5 to s.81 but not others

The petition, however, was dismissed by the High Court as being time-barred.

arguments.claim: RPA is self-contained code excluding Limitation Act provisions per Ponnuswami and Venkateswara Rao

anchor.surface_text: the Representation of the People Act is a complete and self-contained code which does not admit of the introduction of the principles or the provisions of law contained in the Indian Limitation Act.

holdings.text: A Court is not closed notwithstanding the fact that Judges do not sit on any day if otherwise the Court is open on that day.

anchor.surface_text: A long course of decisions have held that a Court is not closed notwithstanding the fact that Judges do not sit on any day if otherwise the Court is open on that day.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Long course of precedents establish that court remains open for filings if office functions, even without judicial sittings.

holdings.text: S. 10 of the General Clauses Act will certainly apply to election petitions to be filed under the Act.

anchor.surface_text: It is, in our view unnecessary to examine the submission in this context because even if s. 4 of the Limitation Act does not apply, S. 10 of the General Clauses Act will certainly apply to election petit-ions to be filed under the Act as held by this Court in H.H. Raja Harinder Singh v. Karnail Singh

holdings.reasoning_summary: Supreme Court precedent in H.H. Raja Harinder Singh confirms applicability regardless of Limitation Act s.4.

holdings.text: Reading rr. 6 and 7 with r. 26, there can be no manner of doubt that an election petition can be presented on the last day of limitation even when the Judges are not sitting to receive or entertain an election petition to the Registrar.

anchor.surface_text: In our view, therefore, reading rr. 6 and 7 with r. 26, there can be no manner of doubt that an election petition can be presented on the last day of limitation even when the Judges are not sitting to receive or entertain an election petition to the Registrar

holdings.reasoning_summary: Harmonious construction of Patna HC Election Rules 6,7 with HC Rule 26 allows presentation to Registrar when no judges/bench available.

holdings.text: The provisions of s. 5 of the Limitation Act do not govern the filing of election petitions or their trial.

anchor.surface_text: For all these reasons we have come to the conclusion that the provisions of s. 5 of the Limitation Act do not govern the filing of election petitions or their trial

holdings.reasoning_summary: RPA is complete self-contained code; s.29(2) Limitation Act inapplicable as scheme of ss.81,82,86,117 excludes ss.4-24 Limitation Act; precedents like Venkateswara Rao.

holdings.text: The Representation of the People Act is a complete and self-contained code which does not admit of the introduction of the principles or the provisions of law contained in the Indian Limitation Act.

anchor.surface_text: the Representation of the People Act is a complete and self-contained code which does not admit of the introduction of the principles or the provisions of law contained in the Indian Limitation Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Scheme mandates dismissal under s.86 for non-compliance with ss.81,82,117 without condonation; mirrors but excludes Limitation Act provisions per precedents Ponnuswami, Venkateswara Rao.

holdings.text: The appeal as well as C.M.P.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal as well as C.M.P.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Petition time-barred as filed after March 18, 1972; no extension available; upholds High Court dismissal.

precedents.cited_proposition: Saturday is a court day even if judges not sitting

precedents.cited_proposition: Court offices remain open for presentation of pleadings even if judicial sittings adjourned or judge not present
precedents.cited_holding: The Judicial sittings of the Court may be adjourned but the offices of the Court may still remain open for the presentation of pleading,- The Court may be open for this purpose although the Judge is not engaged in judicial functions or is not present in the Court-house

anchor.surface_text: A Bench of the Madras High Court in In re. Thokkudubiyyanu Immaniyelu and OtherS 4  dealt with a similar practice which is followed by all High Courts

precedents.cited_proposition: Court reopens on Saturday for receiving papers even if judicial work starts Monday; filing on Saturday if limitation expires then is in time
precedents.cited_holding: the first day of the Court was a Saturday which was the day for receiving papers though the Judges actually sat for judicial work on Monday
